description: From Middle English twinne, twynne, from Old English ƒ°etwin, ƒ°etwinn (‚Äútwin, multiple‚Äù, noun) and twinn (‚Äútwin, two-fold, double, two by two‚Äù, adjective), from Proto-Germanic *twinjaz, *twinaz (‚Äútwo each‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *dwino- (‚Äútwin‚Äù), from *dw√≥h‚ÇÅ (‚Äútwo‚Äù). Cognate with Scots twyn (‚Äútwin‚Äù), Dutch tweeling (‚Äútwin‚Äù), German Zwilling (‚Äútwin‚Äù), Swedish tvilling (‚Äútwin‚Äù), Faroese tvinnur (‚Äúa double set‚Äù), Icelandic tvenna (‚Äúduo, pair‚Äù), Lithuanian dvynys (‚Äútwin‚Äù), Russian –¥–≤–æ–π–Ω—è (dvojnja, ‚Äútwin‚Äù).

entries.meaning: Either of two people (or, less commonly, animals) who shared the same uterus at the same time; one who was born at the same birth as a sibling.
Either of two similar or closely related objects, entities etc.
A room in a hotel, guesthouse, etc. with two beds; a twin room.
(US) A twin size mattress or a bed designed for such a mattress.

verbs.description: twin (third-person singular simple present twins, present participle twinning, simple past and past participle twinned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete outside Scotland) To separate, divide.
(intransitive, obsolete outside Scotland) To split, part; to go away, depart.
(usually in the passive) To join, unite; to form links between (now especially of two places in different countries); to pair with.
examples: Reading, the English town, is twinned with Clonmel in Ireland.
Coventry twinned with Dresden as an act of peace and reconciliation, both cities having been heavily bombed during the war.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be, or be like, a twin to (someone else); to match in some way.
(intransitive) To be, or be like, a pair of twins (for example, to dress identically); to be paired or suited.

description: From Middle English *twin, *twyn, from Old English twin, twinn (‚Äútwin; double‚Äù, adjective), from Proto-Germanic *twƒ´hnaz (‚Äúoccurring in a pair; twofold; double‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *dw√≥h‚ÇÅ (‚Äútwo‚Äù). Cognate with Icelandic tvennur (‚Äúdouble‚Äù), Gothic êçÑêçÖêå¥êåπêå∑êåΩêå∞êåπ (tweihnai, ‚Äútwo each‚Äù).

entries.meaning: Double; dual; occurring as a matching pair.
